history.content:
This schedule is significantly harder than 53+54 imo - in terms of the level of abstract thinking you need for each course (53 and 54 were pretty plug and chug for me, so transitioning to the proof based styles of the above courses was harder). 

I would say its still doable as long as you really stay on top of your work and don't mind doing 3 psets weekly (140 has weekly hws, when I took 127 in sp19 they had weekly hws, and 110 had weekly hws that you didn't have to turn in). 

For context, I took 

- 127 with one other hard tech and felt fine

- 110 with 3 other techs, was pretty stressed

- 140 with two other techs, was a little stressed

But I survived!

children.subject:
For 127 and 140, on the weekly homeworks I probably put about 8-15 hours per homework, spread over the course of the week. I sat a lot in office hours for help. Then you also have the time spent in lectures and discussions (which I found useful both courses, so definitely attend). 

For Math110, I went to every lecture. The textbook was pretty good, but there was still some proofs that I couldn't quite get while reading, and the professor (who was not Paulin so people might say differently) did a good job of explaining things. In my semester of 110, we didn't actually turn in the homeworks, so I would spend about 2-3 hours trying the problems on my own, but I wouldn't stress if I couldn't figure one out, because when the solutions were released, I'd spend about another 2 hours reviewing the solutions for the problems I couldn't figure out. Then I also went to the once a week discussion (because of required quizzes) and stayed for the problems in the last half because they were helpful.  

So 110 was definitely the least workload if the same homework policy is in place next semester (I don't know whose teaching). 

One note: be prepared that 127 will be a bit harder in the beginning of the semester. It requires a more proof based understanding of linear algebra than simply 54 gives you. I took 127 the semester after 110 and felt perfectly comfortable with the material, but expect that if you've only had 54 you'll need a few weeks at the beginning of the semester to get use to thinking about linear algebra in a more abstract way. I love linear algebra,  so I really enjoyed 110+127 - they really teach you a TON of linear algebra.

Thank you ou for the in-depth answer! Just to get an idea of what I might be getting myself into with the above courseload, do you think you could share how much time (roughly) you put into each course? Thank you!

history.content: Thinking about doing this next semester, would it be doable? I'm a math major and I did Math 53 and Math 54, got an A in both.
history.subject: Math 110+EECS 127+Stat 140?
